Enterobacter bugandensis, a newly recognised species, emerges as one of the important opportunistic pathogens within the Enterobacter genus . Species from this Gram-negative, facultative anaerobic genus exist in various environments, from soil to the human gut . Some species act as opportunistic human pathogens, causing nosocomial infections with bactere

The ISS genomes formed a separate clade from strains present in other Earth environments and hosts (Figs.  from human hosts, accounting for approximately 81% of all isolates, followed by non-human hosts/environmental sources (11%) Detailed information on the genomes, including their isolation sources, ANI, is presented in Supplementary Table .

E. bugandensis strains isolated from the ISS might have evolved functionally under extreme conditions . We identified and annotated every open reading frame (ORFs) in each of the 211 genomes/MAG . ISS strains exhibited a relatively higher average gene count in categories such as amino acid transport and metabolism, mobilome (prophages and transposons), and transcription factors .

These genomes harbour resistance to 23 different multidrugs, including cephalosporin, cephamycin, fluoroquinolone, and nitroimidazole antibiotics . A gene from the ACT-77 family (ACT-77) was present across all 13 genomes, exhibiting 99.48% sequence identity and 100% coverage .

The panel illustrates the co-presence networks ( n = 3) of microorganisms that inhabit locations with a relative abundance > 1%. The hexagonal nodes represent ISS locations, while circular nodes symbolise the microorganisms .

Analysis predicted a total of 947 pairwise interactions across seven locations during three flights of the MT-1 mission . Among these interactions, we observed a prevalence of “negative” interactions, such as parasitism (441) and amensalism (412), followed by 34 mutualistic, 31 competitive, 26 commensalistic, and three neutral interactions .

E. bugandensis, a multidrug-resistant, nosocomial BSL-2 pathogen, was observed to be present in the ISS during the cataloguing of viable microbial communities . Such organisms pose potential threats to astronauts on the ISS, though the exact mechanisms behind their behaviour in space remain unknown .

E. bugandensis exhibits prevalence and varying relative abundance across different locations within the space station . DNA retrieved from this opportunistic pathogen residing on ISS is viable and intact .

The metabolic models we constructed are draft models generated from representative type strains of the organisms . These models may still have gaps and could differ from the actual isolates . Despite these limitations, such automated reconstruction models are widely used for studying metabolic characteristics and predicting microbial interactions .

To identify and annotate the ORFs in the genomes of E. bugandensis, we used Prokka v.1.14.6, Prodigal and FreeBayes to identify variants across the provided genomes . We employed the Python package cogclassifier v1.0.5 to identify and classify COGs (Clusters of Orthologous Genes) from
Genome-scale metabolic models (GSMMs) were constructed from the GenBank sequence database . These genomes were processed through KBase to build the models .

To predict the nature of microbial interactions, we employed SteadyCom, an optimisation framework for rapid linear programming problem-solving . This framework allowed us to estimate the biomass production rates of every microbial member in the community in a time-averaged, steady-state manner .
